document.heading: Excepted Service Positions Designation Temporary Amendment Act of 1996

history.narrative: Law 11-156, the “Excepted Service Positions Designation Temporary Amendment Act of 1996,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 11-685. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on May 7, 1996, and June 4, 1996, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on June 17, 1996, it was assigned Act No. 11-284 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 11-156 became effective on September 20, 1996.

ACT 11-284 Codification District of Columbia Code 1997 Supp. IN THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA JUNE 17, 1996 To amend, on a temporary basis, the District of Columbia Government Comprehensive Merit Personnel Act of 1978, to allocate up to an additional 40 Excepted Service positions subject to appointmem by the Mayor to the Office of the Inspector General and, during a control year, up to an additional 20 Excepted Service positions to the Office of the Chief Financial Officer, and to repeal the requirement that lists of Excepted Service positions and incumbents in those positions be published in the District of Columbia Register. BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Excepted Service Positions Designation Temporary Amendment Act of 1996 Sec. 2. Section 903 of the District of Columbia Government Comprehensive Merit Personnel Act of 1978, effective March 3, 1979 (D.C. Law 2-139; D.C. Code § 1-610.3 is amended as follows a) Subsection (a)(2) is amended by adding the following phrase after the word "District except that up to an additional 40 positions subject to appointment by the Mayor shall be allocated to and designated by the Office of the Inspector General and, in a control year, up to an additional 20 positions subject to appointment by the Mayor shall be allocated to and designated by the Office of the Chief Financial Officer b) Subsection (c) is repealed. Sec. 3. The act will have no adverse fiscal impact. Agencies will continue to operate under the FTE ceilings and within budget constraints.
